At 4:07, you said, "I think it's amazing that we, as humans, can conquer so many things about the world around us, but we still struggle with the smallest of things."

Personally, while I love physics, and all of science, I think that humans will never be able to understand what is going on. Sure, we have a lot of theories, and lots of great ideas that keep pushing us in the right direction, but I have a little saying that I think fits the human mind too well- Humans may be doing nothing more than fitting the universe into it's own small interpretation of what is really happening.

I used to find little short cuts in my maths class, trying to bypass all the crazy stuff that explained what was going on, and other classmates even found various ways to come up with the correct answer plenty of times as well. In fact, some of them always had the right answer with the wrong method, no matter how hard we tried to find something wrong with it. There are very many interesting things that go overlooked, and almost always unnoticed, even to the most inquisitive minds. With the expansion of modern technology, in a very unharnessed way (just attend a hacker convention, and say I'm wrong), it's pretty apparent to me that this entire universe is something we will never comprehend.

Is it possible that as the honey leaves the stick, a spin along the flow axis of the tail is induced?  I observe similar stacking behaviors when preparing flexible conduit for painting, and the coiling in that instance is induced because we are spinning it to prepare every part of the external surface.  
In honey, as a viscous fluid, an induced spin would change as it falls because the rotation of each section will pull or slow each other section.  This could create waves of rotational momentum in the fluid which would change properties based on the radius and speed of the fluid.  In this way a spin could produce the coiling behavior you observe (This behavior is obvious with flex conduit because you have better control over the flow and a constant radius.) 
You should be able to test this by adding dye to your honey to stripe it as it falls, this would allow you to better observe in high speed whether the stripes twist along the vertical axis and how it is affected by the flow and radius of the tail when it meets the coil.

More details: Paper 2's diagrams help to picture this. I believe coil radius should increase as velocity (height), stream thickness, and viscosity also increase. Also, odd patterns should be expected if a certain ratio between all 3 variables above is reached. The stream should experience large upward force and want to move outward, but also have enough of an inertial resistance to lateral force to be unable to sustain a large radius, resulting in a wide periodic pattern that hits the center.

I figured it out. Its because of gravity/pressure/momentum. Since the fluid at the bottom is falling much more slowly, the fluid above is experiencing an upward force. It's pretty viscous, so the thing it wants to do most of all is get out of the way. It will fall in an initially random direction, but will be influenced by the angle of the honey below, soon reaching equilibrium between the honey's resistance to lateral force and the upward pressure force, resulting in a coil of constant radius.
If I'm right, you could use the frequency of the coil to work out the molecular frequency at which honey vibrates at a given temperature.

My guess is that the coil only appears uniform when its frequency is in harmonic resonance with the frequency of the "honey particles" vibrating within the suspension of the fluid. I think that conceptually this is not such a complicated problem, but mathematically it gets a bit above my pay grade.  After the initial coil is produced (direction will be stochastically determined), the honey will want to fall as close to vertically as possible.  The radius is determined by how much vertical force is applied by the falling honey as well as how fast the honey stream is able to bend.

As it falls the coil will want to be maintained since the acute angle of the falling honey will give it an energetic advantage to attach in the same direction as the existing coil( since it would be more difficult for it to reverse by 180 degrees), setting up a steady state as a coiling viscous fluid.

The Inertio-gravitational regime displays deterministic chaos (you can determine that there will be chaos). You can describe the different regimes using Feigenbaum's bifurcation diagram. The same thing happens with different flow rates in a dripping faucet. The interesting part is that once you have reached the chaotic part of the diagram (The Inertio-gravitational regime), the behavior flips and you get another reverse bifurcation diagram, until it zeros in at a constant flow again.

I didn't say "freeze"; the glass transition isn't "freezing" in the same sense as, say, water turning into ice (under normal conditions like what you'd find inside your refrigerator's freezer compartment). It is true that some glass panes made hundreds of years ago are thicker at the bottom, this is to do with the manufacturing process.  It was much harder to produce a sheet of glass of uniform thickness back then and so when the pane was made they would mount it thick side down for sturdiness.  They didn't roll sheets of glass back then (before industrialisation) like they do today, but instead they spun it on a large table to get close to uniform thickness.
